description: From Middle English troute, troughte, trught, trouȝt, trouhte, partly from Old English truht (“trout”), and partly from Old French truite; both from Late Latin tructa, perhaps from Ancient Greek τρώκτης (trṓktēs, “nibbler”), from τρώγω (trṓgō, “I gnaw”), from Proto-Indo-European *terh₁- (“to rub, to turn”). The Internet verb sense originated on BBSes of the 1980s, probably from Monty Python's The Fish-Slapping Dance (1972), though that sketch involved a halibut.

nouns.description: trout (countable and uncountable, plural trout or trouts)

entries.meaning: Any of several species of fish in Salmonidae, closely related to salmon, and distinguished by spawning more than once.
examples: Many anglers consider trout to be the archetypical quarry.
Look, you silly old trout, you can't keep bringing home cats! You can't afford the ones you have!

verbs.description: trout (third-person singular simple present trouts, present participle trouting, simple past and past participle trouted)

entries.meaning: (Internet chat) To (figuratively) slap someone with a slimy, stinky, wet trout; to admonish jocularly.
